author: jeffrey.downard
title: DIDs for Cities
description: 如何促进DID广泛采用Atala Prism？

f6_assessments.q0:
One of the main goals for the DID is to be implemented on large scale by local governments first, and then slowly adapt and scale-up to national governments and then on a world-wide scale.
Having a well-documented roadmap and plan to have this implemented is one of the first steps in the right direction, yet if this is not paired in a timely manner with a practical functional d'app, it risks remaining only in a theoretical stage, until someone else shows up with a functioning application.
f6_assessments.q1:
From the details and links they have provided, the team seems highly likely to successfully implement phase 1 of their project, a roadmap for adoption of DIDs and Atala Prism in a small city. 
However, the budget should have been further broken down for better understanding of the necessary team members and particular expenses and/or resources needed. For such a big project, the team should have also taken the time to think about possible risks that might incur during the process, and how they will be mitigating them.
f6_assessments.q2: The budget has been divided in accordance to the timeline which helps visualise the process for the entire project, but there should have been an additional distinction for what each sum will be used for. For example, how will the $3000 for the community outreach be implemented? Or the $6000 in the formulation of the roadmap? Are personnel going to be paid for compiling the roadmap? What skills do they need to have and how many hours are they expected to be working on it? What kind of parameters will be used to determine the success of each step? These pieces of information are vital in the evaluation of the progress.

f6_assessments.q0:
The problem statement is poorly presented as it looks like a questions with multiple answers and not as a sentence that points to a fact. The solutions is taking into consideration the local government as a key player, which, per se, is the antithesis of decentralized is.

Some of the goals of this project should aim to find a real life use case for decentralized ID and to deliver a working product for the people in need for. Saying this, (just) promoting a model of DIDs adoption doesn't fit in the challenge objectives.
f6_assessments.q1:
The experience of the team members is presented briefly without references (links) to validate their expertise (social media, repositories, completed projects etc.).

The budget is outlined and broken down into identifiable items, but some of them are meaningless ("Months 1-5: Project direction", "Month 1: Community outreach" - what is to be done in this phases?).

The presented timeline seems to overlap consecutive Fund Campaigns and thus additional funding might be necessary.

The plan doesn't describe the resources necessary to implement the proposal.

The proposer has not considered challenges and risks relevant to a successful implementation. (why would people want to adopt a decentralized system if the one they used daily works anytime?)
f6_assessments.q2:
The proposal looks more like a concept than as a working product. There are no KPIs/metrics defined to measure the success of the project (Workshops - how many? who is the target audience? how do you measure the audience satisfaction?

The proposal should be reviewed and reworked presenting the necessary and relevant info for a proper assessment and to stand a chance for potential funding.

f6_assessments.q0: the proposal accurately identifies the adoption problem within the challenge. The solution of small city adoption aligns with the proposal. It is slightly unclear what the proposal aims to do once the roadmap for adoption is created and whether or not it will be implemented.
f6_assessments.q1: The team listed appears to have the requisite experience to develop a road map. The funds requested are broken down and the timeframe is reasonable. It would be great to see possible challenges to adoption addressed within the proposal.
f6_assessments.q2: A roadmap is provided and a plan to scale to other cities has also been implemented which does allow for audibility.

solution: 地方政府可以引领潮流。小城市可以树立榜样，作为大城市、州和国家的路线图。
